xocs:funding-list.xocs:funding-text: This work was funded by the Swedish International Development Cooperation Agency , Sida (Grant number 73000992 ). Sida does not necessarily share the views expressed in the paper; responsibility for its contents rests entirely with the author. The author would like to thank three anonymous reviewers for their critiques, which led to a substantial revision of the original paper.

affiliation.address-part: Witthyakit Build., Chulalongkorn Soi 64, Phyathai Rd.

head.citation-title: The inverted pyramid: A neo-Ricardian view on the economy-environment relationship
head.abstracts: © 2014 Elsevier B.V.In ecological economics, natural resources - which may contribute only a small amount to GDP - are viewed as fundamental to the functioning of the economy. They are sometimes pictured as sitting at the base of an inverted pyramid, with the rest of the economy balanced on top of them. In this paper we show that when prices are set by markup, a standard heterodox assumption, then the "inverted pyramid" picture of the economy emerges naturally in a neo-Ricardian model. We demonstrate the use of the model with brief applications to biophysical economics. The paper is one of a growing number that use heterodox macroeconomics to address questions in ecological economics.

affiliation.address-part: Witthyakit Building, Chulalongkorn Soi 64, Phyathai Road

classification.classification-description: ECOLOGICAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES; APPLIED ECOLOGY/POLLUTION; Ecological and Environmental Economics

coredata.dc:description: In ecological economics, natural resources - which may contribute only a small amount to GDP - are viewed as fundamental to the functioning of the economy. They are sometimes pictured as sitting at the base of an inverted pyramid, with the rest of the economy balanced on top of them. In this paper we show that when prices are set by markup, a standard heterodox assumption, then the "inverted pyramid" picture of the economy emerges naturally in a neo-Ricardian model. We demonstrate the use of the model with brief applications to biophysical economics. The paper is one of a growing number that use heterodox macroeconomics to address questions in ecological economics.
coredata.dc:title: The inverted pyramid: A neo-Ricardian view on the economy-environment relationship
